employee_contributions.rate: There are no mandatory social insurance contributions for the employee

data.minimum_wage: In Bangladesh, the National Minimum Wage Board determines the minimum wage for each sector every five years. The current minimum wage is across sectors is up to BDT 12,500 per month for those in the garment industry.

payroll.payroll_cycle: In Bangladesh, the payroll cycle can be daily, weekly, bi-weekly and monthly. Employees salary must be paid by the end of the seventh day after the final day on which the payment is due, according to Bangladesh’s Employee Rights and Labor Law. The same rules are applied for those employees whose employment has been ended by the employer.
payroll.13th_&_14th_salaries: Employees who have completed at least one year of service are entitled to two festival bonuses each year. Each bonus should not be more than the basic salary.

working_hours.general: The standard workweek in Bangladesh is Sunday to Thursday, 9 hours per day, and a weekly maximum of 48 hours.
working_hours.overtime: Additional hours can be worked providing this has been made clear in the employment contract. For certain worker types, overtime is limited to 2 hours per day and paid at a rate of 200% salary.

leave.annual_leave_(vacation): Employees are entitled to 1 day annual leave for every 18 days of work per calendar year (certain industries calculate leave entitlement differently).
leave.public_holidays:
Although Bangladesh has 21 days of national holidays each year, employees are only entitled to take 11 of them off as paid holidays, and it is the employer’s choice as to which ones.
Public holidays that fall on a weekend are lost.
Certain religious holidays are determined by the lunar cycle and will be confirmed nearer the date of the holiday.

leave.sick_days:
Employees are generally entitled to 14 days of paid sick leave per year, paid by the employer, however, this is an annual entitlement and cannot be carried over from year to year.
All employees must present a medical certificate for all absences to receive sick leave and pay.
Casual Leave
Employees are entitled to 10 days paid leave per year for urgent matters such as sudden illness, minor accidents and urgent personal issues. This leave does not accumulate nor carry forward into the following year if unused.
leave.maternity_leave:
Female employees who have worked for at least six months are entitled to 8 weeks of paid maternity leave before the birth and 8 weeks of paid leave after the birth paid by the employer. Women who have worked less than six months or who already have two other surviving children are generally eligible for unpaid leave.
Women are also forbidden to work for eight weeks after the birth of a child.
Women who suffer a miscarriage before the commencement of maternity leave are entitled to 4 weeks paid leave with no deductions from wages during this period.
leave.paternity_leave: There is no provision for paternity leave in Bangladesh. However, some companies do choose to create a paid paternity leave policy.
leave.parental_leave: There is no provision for parental leave.
leave.other_leave: There is no provision for other leave in Bangladesh.

termination.termination_process: Employees with at least one year of service are generally entitled to one month’s notice or pay in lieu of notice and 30 days salary for every year of service.
termination.notice_period:
The notice period is 120 days or payment in lieu of notice can be given. Employees who resign must give 60 days notice.
No notice is required to be given during the probationary period.
termination.severance_pay: Employees who are terminated or resign having completed at least one year with an employer are entitled to severance pay (gratuity) of 30 days’ salary for each completed year of service.
termination.probation_period: Probation periods is a minimum of 3 months and a maximum of 6 months.

visa.general_info:
All foreigners entering Bangladesh require a visa. There are many types of visas for prospective foreign nationals, including business, investor, employment, and NGO working visas. The duration of stay will be worked out by the embassy at which one is applying following a review of required documentation, generally, a valid passport, two passport-size photographs, an application form, and the visa fee.

If expats are going to work in Bangladesh, a work permit is also required. Government bodies tasked with issuing these permits include the Bangladesh Investment Development Authority, the Bangladesh Export Processing Zone Authority, and the NGO Affairs Bureau. The prospective employer will confirm which body to contact.

vat.general: The standard rate of VAT in Bangladesh is 15%.
